Question: A man needs to transport a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage across a river.
He has a small boat that can only carry himself and one item at a time.
If left unattended together, the wolf would eat the goat, and the goat would eat the cabbage.

How can the man transport all three items across the river without any of them being eaten?

First, the setup: There's a man who needs to get a wolf, a goat, and a cabbage across a river.
He has a small boat that can only carry himself and one item at a time.
The problem is that if the wolf and goat are left together, the wolf will eat the goat, and if the goat is left with the cabbage, the goat will eat the cabbage.
So, I need to find a way for all three to get across without any of them being eaten.

1.

2. Wolf eats goat if left together.
3. Goat eats cabbage if left together.
So, the man can't leave any two of them alone.
He has to be present whenever any two items are together.

Wait, but the boat can only carry one item at a time.
So, the man needs to make multiple trips.

1.
The man starts on the left bank with the wolf, goat, and cabbage.
2. He takes one item across to the right bank and returns.
3. He repeats this, ensuring that no two items are left alone in a way that they would eat each other.
